data.title: Feature request: Add "Open with VS Code" to Windows Explorer without reinstall

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I've mentioned this before in another issue, but I though I'd make a new issue since the other one is unrelated & got closed.

Anyways, the only way to add the "Open with VS Code" context menu option to Windows Explorer is to re-install the application. It would be ideal if there was some way to do this in the app without reinstalling it.

For example, Atom has a way to do this in its settings page. Maybe something similar could be done with VS Code.

data.title: Feature request - need more icons in snippets list (for Emmet, custom snippets, etc.)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: win7x64

When you type and see these pile of snippets ...

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24613274/29694356-460967e2-8944-11e7-838b-401691fb7d10.png)

... how can you say, which one is "VSCode core's snippet", and which one is "Emmet snippet"? You can't. You just need to press "Arrow Down" key infinite times to figure it out. I think, that icons at the left of snippet can be more useful.

For example, Emmet icon - ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24613274/29694642-7075c6a4-8946-11e7-9a96-902ec9b304de.png)

how it can be:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24613274/29694620-56b7be48-8946-11e7-92ec-646a877c2969.png)

What do you guys think about it? For my humble opinion, it looks better, and what is really necessary - it is more useful for developer. How is it more useful? When a developer will glance at the list - he will know for sure - 1) that he has required Emmet snippets in the list (there are tons of situations when snippet DO NOT appear, because of user mistake, vscode's bug etc.), and 2) user will choose the right snippet, not vscode core's basic "dry" snippet with nothing in it, but the right Emmet snippet.

Also it would be great to implement user icons (for example,  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24613274/29694854-ea79355c-8947-11e7-8087-4bc18ce5014b.png) ), for custom user snippets in HTML, CSS, JS, etc.

data.title: Reset styling for embedded languages in grammars?
data.body:
# Problem
For grammars with embedded languages, the outside scope's colorization can leak into the embedded language:

![screen shot 2017-08-24 at 4 26 07 pm 1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12821956/29693182-1203fd28-88e9-11e7-809c-104368320484.png)

The above example shows embedding the html grammar in a js template string. Notice that `text` is orange. No specific html grammar scope  applies to it so it picks up the foreground color of `string.template.js`

Instead, in most cases I feel it would make more sense that `text` be colored the same at it would be in a normal html file, which in this case would be the default foreground color of the theme

![screen shot 2017-08-24 at 4 38 32 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12821956/29693473-b07f6e78-88ea-11e7-890d-28620964be20.png)


# Possible Approach
I've already fixed this issue for `${expressions}` in normal js template strings. Manually handling each language and embedded language combination will not scale however. 

One idea is to make themes treat the `meta.embedded` scope as a styling reset point. Themes would just use the same style for `meta.embedded` as for the default:

```
	"tokenColors": [
		{
			"settings": {
				"foreground": "#D4D4D4",
				"background": "#1E1E1E"
			}
		},
		{
			"scope": "meta.embedded",
			"settings": {
				"foreground": "#D4D4D4",
				"background": "#1E1E1E"
			}
		},
      ...
```

This works in my initial testing but may have unintended side effects. It also requires updating every theme

data.title: The Web Optimization Project has optimized your repository!
data.body:
# Web Optimization Project (Beta)

The [Web Optimization Project](https://www.github.com/devedse/weboptimizationproject) is a project that will automatically optimizes files in git repositories by compressing them losslessly. This project was created by [Devedse](https://github.com/devedse) in an effort to save the world! :smirk:

If you have any questions, feel free to create an issue or join the gitter chat:
[![Join the chat at https://gitter.im/WebOptimizationProject/Lobby](https://badges.gitter.im/WebOptimizationProject/Lobby.svg)](https://gitter.im/WebOptimizationProject/Lobby?utm_source=badge&utm_medium=badge&utm_campaign=pr-badge&utm_content=badge)

## Optimization

The Web Optimization Project optimized this repository. All optimizations (compressions) are done losslessly and no quality / data is lost. This is also verified afterwards by the Wop so you can be sure that your images are exactly the same.

## Commits

### Commit 1

Information | Value
-- | --
Version | 0.0.5.0
Support file extension | .PNG .JPG .JPEG .GIF .BMP

#### Statistics

Stats | Value
-- | --
Total optimizable files | 10
Files optimized successfully (size reduced) | 6
Files already fully optimized | 0
Files that failed to be optimized | 4
Total size before optimization | 259.2KB
Total size after optimization | 234.7KB
Optimized size compared to old | 90.55%
Total bytes saved | 24.5KB
Time taken for optimization | 3.1 Minutes

#### Files optimized in this repository

FileName | Original Size | Optimized Size | Bytes Saved | Duration | Successful
-- | -- | -- | -- | -- | --
image.png | 35.9KB | 17.4KB | 18.4KB | 39 Seconds | True
code.png | 5.8KB | 1.7KB | 4.1KB | 1.7 Minutes | True

data.title: Can't use tab.activeBorder with editorGroupHeader.tabsBorder
data.body: I tried the new `tab.activeBorder` but it doesn't work properly on the Ayu themes. The bottom border is hidden. If I decrease the tab element to 34px instead of 35px I can see the border. This is what I would like to achieve (original ST3 theme): I did som adjustments in devtools and got pretty near by doing the following changes: ![screen shot 2017-08-24 at 23 04 48](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/353888/29688637-bb0a65f6-8920-11e7-81be-a26c5ff979e2.png) 1. Removed `overflow: hidden` from selector `.monaco-workbench>.part.editor>.content>.one-editor-silo>.container>.title, .monaco-workbench>.part>.title` 2. Removed inline style `overflow: hidden` on element with class `.monaco-scrollable-element` 3. Added `border-bottom: 1px solid #1d242c` to selector `.monaco-workbench>.part.editor>.content>.one-editor-silo>.container>.title .tabs-container>.tab`

data.title: Add quick find functionality to File Explorer
data.body:
When the File Explorer is in focus, it should be possible to type to select an item from the tree-view.

(Extension API to achieve the same thing would also be nice.)

data.title: cmd+shift+f (Find in Files) should always select the contents of the search field
data.body:
The current behavior is that pressing cmd+shift+f toggles between the editor and the side panel, but this drives me crazy as I need to check my focus before pressing (or not pressing) that combo when doing a lot of hunting around.

The number of times I've accidentally typed my search into a random file instead of the search field is painful. Please make cmd+shift+f always focus the search field, or at least allow for such an option.

This issue was originally closed, here: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/22814#issuecomment-324732891

I'm not certain why this isn't default behavior as it is common in other editors.

Thanks!

data.title: code --uninstall-extension is not the inverse of --install-extension
data.body:
It was surprising to find out that after a:

```bash
code --install-extension ~/Desktop/test.vsix
```

and a restart, executing this:

```bash
code --uninstall-extension ~/Desktop/test.vsix
```

doesn't remove the extension, instead it throws an error:

```bash
Error: Extension '/Users/fabio/Desktop/test.vsix' is not installed.
```

data.title: Store timestamp for filebased extension recommendations
data.body:
Current Model
- Based on file pattern, extension recommendations are made. Once a recommendation is made it is stored in local storage and is shown in the recommendation view of Extension viewlet

Proposed Model in this PR
- Store timestamp along with the extension recommendation, that denotes the time when an extension recommendation is made based on file pattern
- If the timestamp is more than a week old, then remove it from the list
- If no timestamp is found for a recommendation (which can happen when user updates to the new version of VS Code that has these changes), assume current time as timestamp.

cc @jrieken and @joaomoreno who have worked on extension recommendations before according to git blame :)

data.title: Debugging client-server for extension launches 2 server processes after vscode update

data.title: Default Ctrl+R Ctrl+R chord handling
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:05:38.342Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
python|don|0.7.0
EditorConfig|Edi|0.9.4
PowerShell|ms-|1.4.1
Ruby|reb|0.15.0

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Open a JS file or any code file with `editorHasRenameProvider`.  Make a variable and put the cursor inside it.
2. Press and hold the Ctrl key.
3. Press R twice.
4. Release the Ctrl key.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Expected behavior: The variable will be renamed.  (`Ctrl+R Ctrl+R` is the default keyboard chord for renaming a variable in Visual Studio).
Actual behavior: VS Code will close the current project and open up some other project depending on what other things you've recently opened.

I wonder if there is a way to detect the chord and process the rename action.  `Ctrl+R Ctrl+R` is a keyboard shortcut that has been reinforced through years of muscle memory from using full Visual Studio.  Adding `{ "key": "ctrl+r ctrl+r",                "command": "editor.action.rename",
        "when": "editorHasRenameProvider && editorTextFocus && !editorReadonly" }` appears to make stand-alone Ctrl+R not work because VS Code will be waiting for the second chord.  I am willing to forgo this, but I am wondering if there is a way to support the rename action and recent files.  Sorry for the "not a bug" ticket, but it's just very frustrating to keep getting thrown out of my project when I'm just trying to do some refactoring.  :-(
